newsitem.title: USA: Primakov says Russia won't change on NATO.
newsitem.headline: Primakov says Russia won't change on NATO.

text.p: Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov met U.S. President Bill Clinton Monday but said afterwards Russia would not change its opposition to NATO expansion.

"Russia will not change its position on NATO. But Russia understands that NATO is a real force, and Russia wants to have normal relations with NATO, which would serve the cause of normalising the situation in Europe," Primakov told reporters after seeing Clinton at the White House.

White House spokesman Mike McCurry said Primakov and Clinton had a "good review" of the issues to be addressed later this week at a summit between Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin in Helsinki. Clinton and Yeltsin are expected to seek an accommodation over NATO's plan to expand into Eastern Europe.

Asked whether there had been any change in positions during the one-hour session between Clinton and Primkov, McCurry said "there's still work to be done." But he said this did not keep the U.S.-Russian relationship from being productive.
"There will likely continue to be some disagreements after the summit in Helsinki," McCurry told reporters. "I can't imagine that we will solve all the issues that are pending."

McCurry said Clinton stated that "the United States and Russia are in this relationship for the long haul." But, McCurry said, "there is a substantial amount of work that needs to be done to clear away the residue of the Cold War period. A large part of the work of this summit will be about that."
